title: Evaluating the Effect of Retrieval Augmentation on Social Biases
author: Tianhui Zhang (University of Liverpool), Yi Zhou (Cardiff University), Danushka Bollegala (University of Liverpool), ...
relevance_why: The paper examines how retrieval augmented generation can amplify social biases in generated texts which is relevant for creating debiased audio generation systems applicable in audio and speech tasks.
field: Social and Economic Aspects of ML-Fairness
background: The study investigates how social biases from document collections affect outputs of language models when real-time retrieval is employed.
contribution: This paper introduces a thorough evaluation of social biases in retrieval-augmented generation systems, showing that biases in document sets can amplify biases in generated outputs across multiple languages and bias types.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous research primarily focused on individual LLM biases without considering the external effects of document collections used in RAG.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work systematically assesses the interaction between retrieval mechanisms and underlying biases within language models.

key_innovation: Analyzes the amplification of social biases through document retrieval in multilingual contexts, revealing implications for model deployment in real-world applications.
real_world_impact: The findings highlight the need for careful document curation in systems that utilize retrieval augmentation, informing practices to mitigate social bias in AI applications.
limitations: The study does not explore all possible combinations of model architectures and retrieval methods or other languages outside the selected three.

new_terms.Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG): **Retrieval Augmented Generation** refers to a method that employs external document retrieval to provide information and context to language models during generation tasks, improving factual accuracy but potentially affecting bias.
